Since he is the main breadwinner for the family and his income isn't enough to cover all their needs, Khaled applied for a loan from Kiva's partner Al Majmoua to help him to pay his daughter's school fees. 

In the future, Khaled dreams of developing his business by increasing his buses and expanding his working zone.

loans.use: To pay for his daughter's school fees.

loans.name: Rosa

texts.en:
Rosa is 63 years old and widowed with three children. She works very hard to provide for them.

Rosa runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 24,000 loan through NWTF to buy more stock to sell in her general store.  She has been in this business for 10 years and sells a variety of items such as bath soap, sugar, soft-drinks, canned goods and other groceries. 

In the future, Rosa would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more stock to sell in her general store.

loans.name: Kolaban Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe kolaban, composé de femmes mariées, ont en moyenne 32 ans, 4 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à Dioïla, quartier Tripano, préfecture de Dioïla, Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et d’amitié. Elles font le commerce du lait et de savon.                                                                 
Les femmes du groupe kolaban sont à leur quatrième prêt solidaire. 
La cliente Minata première personne à partir de la droite dans le rang des debout, est vendeuse de savons. Elle a une clientèle mixte. Son cycle d’approvisionnement est chaque semaine. Elle compte acheter 5 cartons de diverses sortes de savons auprès des grossistes.
Elle envisage après toutes dépenses réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 30 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour ses besoins de la famille et une partie est réinvestie dans l’activité.
texts.en:
The women belonging to the group called Kolaban, made up of married women, have an average age of 32 and on average, four children. They all live in traditional extended families in Dioïla, Tripano district, prefecture of Dioïla, Koulikoro region (second administrative region of the Republic of Mali.) 

They met each other through bonds of kinship, neighborhood and friendship. They sell milk and soap. The women of the Kolaban group are on their fourth solidarity loan. 

Minata, the first person on the right, standing, sells bars of soap. She has a mixed clientele and buys her inventory every week. She intends to buy five cartons of various sorts of bars of soap from wholesalers. 

Minata expects to make, after expenses, an average monthly profit of 30,000 F CFA which will be used for family needs with a part reinvested in her business.

loans.use: to buy bars of soap.

loans.name: Juu Kwa Juu Group

texts.en:
ELIZABETI is in her late twenties, and she is married with one daughter. The girl is still young. For a period of four years now, ELIZABETI has had a business selling clothes. She is doing fine in her project and her family also. She starts working from8:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. daily and is able to make a good profit per month. 

This is her first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania which she will use to increase her stock of clothes to resell. ELIZABETI dreams to one day be able to build a nice house for her family and provide better education for her kid. 

She will share this loan with her loan group "Juu Kwa Juu" which totals 11 members. The members will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to increase her stock of clothes to resell.

loans.name: Caridad

texts.en:
Caridad is 50 years old, is married and has seven children, two of whom are in school. She has been in the agricultural business for five years now raising pigs in the Philippines. 

Caridad has requested a PHP 16,000 loan through NWTF to purchase feed and vitamins for her pigs.She has borrowed 12 times in the past from NWTF to sustain her business. Caridad would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase feed and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Cynthia

texts.en: Cynthia is 44 years old and married with two children.  She earns a living by farming rice in the Philippines. Cynthia is borrowing PHP 20,000 through NWTF to buy fertilizer and other farm supplies.  Cynthia has been farming rice for 2 years and also earns additional income from a general store.  She is working tirelessly towards realizing her dream which is to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and other farm supplies.

loans.name: Elsie

texts.en:
As a married parent of nine children, Elsie works hard to support her family.

She has a fishing business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from raising pigs. Elsie is borrowing PHP 22,000 through NWTF to buy fishing materials for her fishing business.

Elsie has been sustaining her business activities through her past 6 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy fishing materials for her business.

loans.name: Kotognotala  I Group

texts.fr:
Les dix  membres du  KOTOGNOTALA  I sont des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 36 ans et ont en moyenne 3 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à Fofanabougou un des villages de la commune de Guégnaka,  préfecture de Dioîla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de micro finance Soro yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités en début d’hivernage. Les spéculations cultivées sont culture de l’arachide, du mil et du sésame. Elles sont à leur quatrième  collaboration avec l’institution.
Avec ce prêt,  Mama la personne au milieu dans le rang des assises, compte acheter les intrants, les petits équipements et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir environs 1 ha de mil et d’arachide 
Les productions sont vendues au niveau de la ville de Fana, après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice  de 125 000F CFA environs par campagne.
texts.en:
The 10 members of the group called  KOTOGNOTALA  I are married women with an average age of 36 and on average, three children. Most of them live in polygamous families in Fofanabougou, one of the villages of the community of Guégnaka,  prefecture of Dioîla, Koulikoro region, second administrative region of Mali. 

They collaborate with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso with the goal of better organizing their activities at the start of the rainy season. The crops they cultivate are peanuts, millet and sesame. They are on their fourth loan with the institution. 

With this loan, Mama, the person in the middle of the seated row, intends to buy farm inputs, tools, and pay the fees for plowing etc. to maintain around a hectare of millet and peanuts. Her produce is sold in the town of Fana, after the harvest, to a clientele composed of men and women. She expects to make a profit of 125,000 F CFA, more or less, per growing season.

loans.use: to pay for plowing, seeds, fertilizer, herbicide, weeding and small equipment.

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
Anita is 39 years old and is married with four children. She lives in Calamba, Misamis Occidental. Anita owns and operates an agricultural business, growing and selling vegetables in the local community to earn a living.  Aside from farming, she also operates a general store selling goods in the community. 

Anita joined GDMPC in 2011 and she has now requested a loan of 10,000 PHP to purchase canned goods, noodles and sugar to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase canned goods, noodles and sugar to sell

loans.name: Julita

texts.en:
As a parent of three children, Julita works hard to support her family. She has a pig fattening business in the Philippines and earns additional income from a general store. She has been sustaining her business activities through her past four loans from NWTF.  

Julita is borrowing PHP 10,000 through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pig fattening business. She has successfully repaid her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her business.

Julita hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pig fattening business

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a fruit-vending business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 16,500 through NWTF to buy additional fruit to sell in her fruit-vending business.

Evelyn has been in this business for 20 years. Evelyn earns additional income from native bags/mats making and a general store.

Evelyn has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of repairing and renovating her family home in the future.

loans.use: to buy additional fruit to sell.

loans.name: Diwani

texts.en:
As a married parent of three children, Diwani works hard to support her family.

She has a furniture-making business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from a general store.  Diwani is borrowing PHP 10,000 through NWTF to buy additional materials like bamboo, paint, nails, etc for her furniture-making business.

Diwani has been sustaining her business activities through her past 22 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy additional materials like bamboo, paint and nails for her business.

loans.name: Martha

texts.en:
For the past six years, she has operated a poultry business. She operates from home and her potential customers are neighbours and passers-by. She faces a major challenge of seasonality and disease out-breaks in her business. She dreams of expanding her business to accommodate more hens in the future.

With the KES 50,000 she wants to purchase feed for the chickens and also buy more chicks for her business. She decided to join to Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase feed for her chickens and also buy more chicks for her business.

loans.name: Brenda

texts.en:
Brenda previously accessed a 12,000 PHP loan that she used to buy more products like meats, rice, vegetables, condiments and seasonings. Her earnings were a big help for her children's education and in their personal, household and business expenditures.

Brenda would like to apply for another 15,000 PHP loan so she can purchase raw ingredients and supplies needed in her business. Her profits from the business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs and her children's educational expenses. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Brenda dreams of making continuous progress in her business and hopes to have their own house. She meets with her co-fellowship members every week, to share stories of her work and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God that she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: to buy raw ingredients like rice, pork, chicken and vegetables and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Carmencita

texts.en:
Carmencita is married and they have been blessed with seven children. At the age of 52, Carmencita is determined to earn more income for her family. Vegetable vending is her business from which she earns a net daily income of PHP 300. 

Due to her lack of capital, Carmencita is asking for a loan amounting to PHP 20,000 to purchase five kilos of eggplant and 10 kilos of string beans to sell. She's hoping that her business will become more profitable and more productive.

loans.use: To purchase five kilos of eggplant and 10 kilos of stringbeans to sell

loans.name: Jenalyn

texts.en:
Jenalyn is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a business buying and selling charcoal in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 18,000 through NWTF to buy additional sacks of charcoal for her business. 

Jenalyn has been in this business for three years. Jenalyn earns additional income from a general store.

She successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her charcoal and general store businesses.

Jenalyn has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving money for business expansion in the future.

loans.use: to buy additional sacks of charcoal for her business.

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina is a widow. She lives in her own house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food.

Amina operates a food-making business, making items such as beans and chapati (flat bread) for sale to passersby and neighbours. She mentioned that her major challenge is the high cost of purchasing food items. 

With the Kshs 50,000, Amina wants to purchase food items such as wheat flour, cooking oil, sugar and beans. She dreams of expanding her business to earn more income and of establishing a restaurant in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase food items such as wheat flour, cooking oil, sugar and beans.

loans.name: Asif

texts.en:
Asif is a 38-year-old man who lives with his family in Lahore, Pakistan. He has been running his own general store near his house. He belongs to a poor family. He wishes to provide higher education for his children; however, due to low income and savings, he is unable to fullfil his wish.

Asif is an active borrower of BRAC Pakistan. He currently needs to purchase some products for his store including soaps, body spray, hair dye, shampoos and lotions, etc. However, due to financial constraints, he is finding this difficult. Therefore, he has requested a loan from Kiva's partner, BRAC Pakistan. This will not only help him to grow his business but will also increase his net income and savings. He is very thankful to Kiva and BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of products to sell.

loans.name: Pervaiz

texts.en:
Pervaiz is a 52-year-old married man. He is an active borrower of BRAC Pakistan. He lives in Lahore, Pakistan, with his family. His wife is a very hardworking and responsible housewife. 

Since 1992, Pervaiz has been in the business of selling milk, which is the only source of income for the family. Currently he is interested in purchasing one buffalo to grow his business but finds it difficult due to financial constraints. 

Pervaiz has requested a loan from Kiva's partner, BRAC Pakistan. This will not only help him to grow his milk-selling business but will increase his net income and savings as well. He hopes to provide quality education for his children. He is very thankful to Kiva and BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: To purchase buffalo to sell milk.

loans.name: Gina

texts.en: Gina is 49 years of age, married, and blessed with five children. Working hard is her key to success, she earns income from banana vending and has been doing this for almost 3 years. Due to a lack of capital she's requesting a loan of PHP 15,000 to purchase 100 kilos of bananas to sell. She's hoping that her business will continue to improve and expand.

loans.use: To purchase 100 kilos of bananas to sell

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia is from the village of Calamba, Misamis Occidental. Her husband is a fisherman and she helps him to earn a living by selling fish in town. She has been in this business for more than 10 years. 

Cecilia borrowed a loan from GDMPC microcredit, which she had joined recently, in order to buy fishing nets to be used for fishing. She hopes to save more for the renovations of her house.

loans.use: to buy fishing nets

loans.name: Tarek

texts.en:
Tarek is a 21-year-old single man. He is employed in a company where, for the last three years, he has been responsible for finishing all the required legal government documents. He used to work as a chef, but the country's security situation made any work based on tourism very hard to develop, and that's why he turned to an administrative job. Tarek is responsible for supporting his three other family members, so he has to work hard to increase his income in order to cover their expenses.

He is applying for a loan from Kiva's partner, Al Majmoua, in order to undergo a necessary operation.

loans.use: To undergo a necessary operation.

loans.name: Maria Eda

texts.en: Maria Eda is a 47-year-old married woman from Talibon, Bohol. She has 3 children, ages 18, 17 and 7 respectively. She is engaged in a pottery making business. She makes pots for flowers and decorative jars for indoors. To be able to continue its operation, Maria Eda requested a loan of 25,000 PHP to buy materials used in pottery making, as well as lumber and nipa for where the pots are being stored. In the future, Maria Eda would like to expand her pottery making business to support her family and also to save for the education of her children.

loans.use: to buy materials used in pottery making, and lumber and nipa for where the pots are being stored.

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria is a resident of Payatas, Philippines. She is 51 years old and is happily married to Efraim who works as a foam dealer. God has blessed them with loving children. Life indeed is hard. But by the grace of God, they were able to raise their children well and they are helping each other in working for their family.

Gloria owns a variety store. This is a small store that can be owned by anyone in the community: the store is connected to or just inside their houses. This is where you can buy a sachet of shampoo or conditioner, a bar of soap, a 5 PHP-worth of cooking oil, an egg, etc. Gloria buys her products from a wholesaler at a lower price;  then she sells it per piece for a higher price to earn a profit. Her regular customers are her neighbours, passersby and the people in the community. She earns PHP 300 a day.

To be able to expand her inventory, Gloria is requesting a PHP 23,000 loan. She will use the loan to buy grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business. This loan will be a great help for her in adding more products to her store.

Gloria dreams of having other sources of income and hopes that her children will finish their studies. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and there she can also draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies.

All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: to buy grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Filipina

texts.en:
As a married parent of five children, Filipina works hard to support her family.

She runs a piggery in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from a general store and selling meat. Filipina is borrowing PHP 29,500 through NWTF to purchase additional feed for her pigs and to repair her pig pens.

She successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan.

Filipina has been sustaining her business activities through her past 21 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional feed for her pigs and to repair her pig pens

loans.name: Mary Grace

texts.en:
As a married parent of one child, Mary Grace works hard to support her family.

She has a buying-and-selling dried coconut meat business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from pig fattening. Mary Grace is borrowing PHP 25,000 through NWTF to buy dried coconut meat for her business.

Mary Grace has been sustaining her business activities through her past 6 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy dried coconut meat for her business.

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en:
Mary Jane is 33 years old, married and has four children who are in school. 

Mary Jane is in the pig fattening business in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 29500 loan through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Mary Jane has been pig fattening for 12 years now, and has borrowed 11 times in the past from NWTF to grow and maintain the business.

In the future, Mary Jane would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to school.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Kadzo

texts.en:
Kadzo has operated a clothing business, selling at the market to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of stiff competition in her business. She dreams of expanding and establishing a boutique business in the future. 

With the loan that she is requesting, of KES 40,000, she wants to purchase bales of clothes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business and she appreciates the support.

loans.use: to purchase bales of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is married, and has six children. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past seven years, she has operated a fruit and vegetable selling business. She sells to her neighbours and passersby. Her major challenges are the high cost of transportation to her place of operation.

With the KES 25,000 she wants to purchase sacks of fruits and vegetables for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business and improve her living standards.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of fruits and vegetables for resale

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en:
Hellen operates a poultry business from home whereby neighbours and passersby are her potential customers. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business.

She decided to join to Yehu to access loans to boost her business. With the Kshs 50,000 loan, Hellen wants to purchase 10 hens and chicken feed for her business. She dreams of expanding her business to accommodate more hens in the future.

loans.use: to purchase 10 hens and chicken feed for her business

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en:
Mohamad is a 36-year-old married father of three children. He has been employed in an company for nine years. His wife doesn't work, and two of his children are currently enrolled in a public school which increases the burden on him to work harder in order to meet his family's needs. 

Mohamad is applying for a loan from Kiva's partner Al Majmoua, to buy a car. This will facilitate most of his family needs, and will help him because he plans to start a business of his own.

loans.use: To buy a car to facilitate his family's needs.

loans.name: Touch

texts.en:
Touch is 38 years old and has a life partner. He lives with his wife and some children in Kompong Cham province. Touch and his wife are operating on almost one hectare of farmland, where they grow rice to serve the family as food. He also gains an income from a service-based business, providing transportation to the people living in the surrounding areas. Touch has great support from some of his children who are employed in various positions within the province. 

Touch wants to help his children with their transportation needs, as they usually go to work by renting a motor-taxi service. Touch is taking this loan in order to buy a motorcycle for his children. He believes that he can help his children reduce their costs and, to some extent, their needs. This will be his fourth loan from HKL and his first loan from Kiva, which will allow him to advance his standard of living.

loans.use: to buy a motorcycle for his children.

loans.name: Ma.nonita

texts.en: Ma.Nonita is a 44 year old married woman from Talibon, Bohol. She has 7 children. The oldest is 18 while the youngest is 6. She runs a sari-sari (variety) store. She sells items like sugar, biscuits, noodles, soft drinks and shampoo. Her husband goes fishing, to help meet the family's daily needs. Ma.Nonita  requested  a loan of 30,000 PHP to buy more goods like toiletries, noodles, condiments and beverages to sell. In the future, Ma.Nonita would like to expand her sari-sari store business to support her family more.

loans.use: to buy more goods like toiletries, noodles, condiments and beverages to sell

loans.name: Julita

texts.en:
Julita is a food stall owner. Aside from her food stall, she also has a variety store. Her businesses are going strong and her loans help her in many ways. She used the last loan as additional capital for her business, and as a result she can generate more income. She continues to work for her family.

She would like to apply for another 25,000 PHP loan to buy raw ingredients like rice, pork, chicken, vegetables and other products needed in her business. The profits from her business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Julita hopes to be more successful in her business ventures and dreams to give a good life to her family. She meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week, and this is where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies. 

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy raw ingredients like rice, pork, chicken, vegetables and other products needed in her business.

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
At the age of 20, Marites got married. She finished her tertiary level of education, but she prefers to run a business. She manages a bakery and a retail store business in the market, while her husband is a farmer.

According to her, she needs to work hard to improve her sales, and she wanted to encourage more customers to buy the products she sells, in order to earn more profits. She wants to support her children and immediately provide their needs in pursuing their education. 

Marites is asking for a loan amounting to Php 40,000 to buy flour and other raw materials for making breads, and also drinks. She works very hard for the better future of the children.

loans.use: To buy flour and other raw materials for making breads, and also drinks.

loans.name: Indolesa

texts.en:
Indolesa is from Calamba, Misamis Occidental.  She is 58 years old, married and has three children. 

To make a living, Indolesa runs a general store, selling a variety of food and home products in the local community. 

Indolesa is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP to purchase dried fish and bagoong (a fish condiment) in addition to her product offerings. 

In 2011, Indolesa joined GDMPC to access financial services to improve her business and living situation. 

She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to create a reserve for future emergencies.			.

loans.use: to purchase dried fish and bagoong in addition to her product offerings.

loans.name: Elma

texts.en:
Elma lives in the village of Calamba, Misamis Occidental, where she runs a store and cooks chicharon for sale. (Chicharon is a dish made of fried pork rinds. It is sometimes made from chicken, mutton, or beef.) 

Her husband is a farmer, and she helps him earn a living through her food production and selling in town. She is 39 years old and a proud mother of two children. She joined GDMPC in 2011 and is now requesting a loan to buy raw ingredients and groceries to sell. She hopes to renovate their house with the generated income.

loans.use: to buy raw ingredients and groceries to sell.

loans.name: Merisyl

texts.en:
This is Merisyl. Her previous loan was a big help in her business. She was able to buy more products for her variety store. Her income helped her in financing her children's education as well as their household expenses.

She would like to apply for another 14,000 PHP loan for her to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add into her inventory. The more items displayed at the store the better. More items to sell will result in better profit. The profits from her business will definitely help sustain her family’s daily needs and her children’s education expenses. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Merisyl dreams of being more successful in her business and hopes that her children will finish their studies. She meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week, where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Chanthorn's Group

texts.en:
Chanthorn, 45, is the mother of one child who is still in school. She strives for a living via rice farming, with the support from her husband. This business has returned her about 36,000 KHR per day. 

Chanthorn’s previous loan was her first loan with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner). She has fully repaid her previous loan, which has improved her standard of living in a gradual manner. 

She is now leading a group of four to apply for a new loan.  As the leader, she will spend her loan portion to buy fertilizer and insecticide for her farmland.  She hopes that she can make more income from her business, and keep improving her living conditions.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, insecticide, and gasoline for her farmland

loans.name: Maria Del Carmen

texts.es:
María, es viuda y disfruta de tres hijos, los cuales tiene 25, 38 y 45 años de edad, todos trabajan y le ayudan para salir adelante. Ella, se dedica a la venta de coco, asimismo posee una tienda, dicha actividad la realiza todos los días de 8:00am a 4:00pm.
El préstamo que requiere le permitirá comprar productos de primera necesidad tales como: frijoles, arroz, azúcar, sal, entre otros y cocos; esta inversión le ayudara a aumentar su calidad de venta para mejorar sus utilidades y capacidad de pago.
Su sueño es sacar adelante a sus hijos y que sean profesionales.
texts.en:
María is a widow and she enjoys her three children who are 25, 38 and 45 years old. They all work and they help her get ahead. She works selling coconuts, and she has a store. She works at this activity every day from 8:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m.

The loan she needs will allow her to buy staple products such as beans, rice, sugar and salt, as well as coconuts. This investment will help her to increase her sales capacity to improve her profits and her payment capacity.  

Her dream is to get her children ahead and for them to have good careers.

loans.use: to buy beans, rice, sugar, salt, coconuts and more.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
As the married parent of three children, Elizabeth works hard to support her family.

She has a general store business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from a buy and sell charcoal business. Elizabeth is borrowing PHP 20,000 through NWTF to purchase additional stock to sell, like canned goods, milk, coffee, eggs, spices, etc. for her general store business.

Elizabeth has been sustaining her business activities through her past 13 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock to sell like canned goods, milk, coffee, eggs, spices, etc...

loans.name: Aigul

texts.ru: Айгуль, 39 лет, замужем, многодетная мать, имеет 4 детей (3 сына и 1 дочь). С 2004 года занимается полеводством и животноводством. Благодаря своему трудолюбию и целеустремленности Айгуль смогла развить полеводческую деятельность, также есть свое хозяйство. В хозяйстве имеется: 2 дойные коровы, 2 лошади, 3 жеребца, 2 бычка и 70 овец. Обрабатывает 1,20 ГА земли, где сажает картофель и фасоль. Супруг Айгуль занимается частным извозом пассажиров. Дополнительным доходом Айгуль, также является продажа молока из дома. В целях дальнейшего развития своего  хозяйства и полеводства Айгуль обратилась в Микрофинансовый Банк «Бай-Тушум и Партнеры» за кредитом в сумме 60 000 сом (KGS) на покупку телят и удобрений для картофеля. Доходы от кредита Айгуль планирует вложить в дальнейшее увеличение количества скота в своем хозяйстве, а также в будущем хочет построить новый сарай для скота. Айгуль входит в состав группы "Келечек-Н", в составе группы 3 человека и Айгуль является одним из членов группы.
texts.en: Aigul is 39 years old, she is married and has four children: three sons and one daughter. Since 2004 she has been doing field crop cultivation and animal husbandry. Aigul was able to grow her crop cultivation business thanks to her love for work and her purposefulness. She has a cattle business which includes two milk cows, two horses, three stallions, two calves and seventy sheep. She cultivates 1.20 hectares of land where she plants potato and beans. Aigul's husband is a driver. As an additional income, Aigul sells milk from home. She has come to the microfinance bank Bai Tushum and Partners for a loan in the amount of 60,000 som (KGS) to buy calves and fertilizer for potatoes with the goal to further grow her business. Aigul plans to invest the income from the loan into further increase of headcount of cattle in her business and also wants to build a new shed for the livestock. Aigul is in the Kelechek-N group which has three people and Aigul is a member of this group.

loans.use: to buy calves and fertilizer.

loans.name: Sanoun's Group

texts.en:
Originally from the Kror Kor district of Pursat province, Sanoun is 49 years old and the widowed mother of seven children. Her two and half hectare rice farm has returned her about 17,000 KHR per day. 

This is the sixth loan for Sanoun with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner).  The past loans, which she has fully repaid, have afforded her to provide decent food for her children. 

Now, she leads a group of two to apply for a new loan. As the leader, she will spend her loan portion to pay for a plowing fee for her farmland. 

She hopes that she can increase her yield, and get a better profit than before.

loans.use: To pay a plowing fee for her farmland

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy organic fertilizer to increase production and pay the laborers who help him clear his farm.

loans.name: Nadeem

texts.en:
Nadeem is a 48-year-old married man. He is an active borrower of BRAC Pakistan. He lives in Lahore, Pakistan with his family. His wife is a very hardworking and responsible housewife. He belongs to a poor family and has been sustaining his family life, although there have been many hurdles. He has many wishes for his family, such as to provide higher education for his children and to provide good facilities for his family. However he has insufficient income and savings to fulfill his dreams. Still he strongly believes that one day his life will take a good turn and Allah will shower blessings on his family.

Nadeem owns a hardware shop where he sells a variety of paints, paint brushes and paint oils. This shop is the only source of income for the family. 

Currently, he is interested in purchasing a variety of paints, but finds it difficult due to financial constraints. Nadeem has requested a loan from Kiva's partner BRAC Pakistan. This will not only help him to grow his business but will increase his net income and savings as well. He is very thankful to Kiva and BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of paints to sell.

loans.name: Ma. Genely

texts.en:
As a married parent of four children, Ma. Genely works hard to support her family.

She has a general store business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from raising pigs. Ma. Genely is borrowing PHP 19000 through NWTF to buy additional items like coffee, canned goods, bath soap, laundry soap, eggs, noodles and other groceries to sell in her general store.

Ma. Genely has been sustaining her business activities through her past 19 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy additional items like coffee, canned goods, bath soap, laundry soap, eggs, noodles and other groceries to sell in her general store

loans.name: Marina

texts.en:
Marina is 55 years old and married with eight children.

Marina works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and has requested a PHP 17000 loan through NWTF to buy items to sell like soap, milk, canned goods, noodles, eggs, etc..

Marina has borrowed and paid 3 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 3 years and also earns an income from farming rice.

Marina aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy items to sell like soap, milk, canned goods, noodles, eggs, etc.

loans.name: 24 De Mayo Group

texts.es:
El comité “24 de mayo” se formo con 13 mujeres que trabajan y se están esforzando por salir adelante. Cada una de ellas tiene su propio emprendimiento en el que están poniendo todos sus esfuerzos por salir adelante. Son de una comunidad alejada y se puede decir de difícil acceso, bastante rural, en vías de crecimiento.
Georgina es la presidenta de este grupo, ella esta criando animales de corral, y por medio de esto tiene los ingresos para su día a día y el de su familia. Tiene todo tipo de animales, como ser patos, gallinas, y cerdos. Es muy sacrificada esta señora, pero cuenta que todo lo que hace es por ayudar a su familia.
Solicita de este crédito para poder invertirlo en la compra de balanceados para sus animales, y de esa forma poder seguir con la cría de ellos.
texts.en:
The “24 de mayo” committee was formed with 13 women who work and who are striving to get ahead. Each of them has her own enterprise in which she is putting all of her efforts to get ahead. They are from a remote community which can be said to have difficult access. It is very rural and is is experiencing growth. 

Georgina is the president of this group. She is raising penned animals and through this has income to live on day to day with her family. She has all types of animals, such as ducks, chickens and pigs. This woman works very hard, but she says that everything she does is to help her family. 

She is asking for this loan to be able to invest it in buying balanced feed for her animals, and in this way be able to continue raising them.

loans.use: to buy balanced feed for animals.

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
As a married parent of eight children, Norma works hard to support her family.

She has a vegetable buying and selling business in the Philippines and also earns additional income from pig fattening. Norma is borrowing PHP 29500 through NWTF to buy vegetables for her business. 

She successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her vegetable vending and pig fattening business.

Norma has been sustaining her business activities through her past 20 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy vegetables for her business

loans.name: Pedro Antonio

texts.es:
Pedro tiene 50 años de edad, esta acompañada y tiene dos hijos. Es muy conocido además de ser una de las personas más activas de la comunidad, él se dedica al comercio mantiene una pequeña tienda muy humilde y vive con su esposa y sus 2 nietos, una niña de 8 años y el niño de 3 años, los cuales manifiesta son su adoración y por los cuales lucha día a día, de mantener la tienda ya lleva 6 años la cual pues les genera pequeñas entradas. Antes de tener la tienda se dedicaba al cuido de una hacienda ya que por motivos de una mala administración la Hacienda cerró y es por eso que hoy en día solo se mantiene de las entradas de la tienda. 

En este caso los productos que él vende la mayoría de estos los tiene que salir a comprar a la ciudad, por lo que tiene que desplazarse 64 kilómetros de distancia, lo cual se desplaza por medio del transporte colectivo el cual tarda aproximadamente una hora y treinta minutos hasta llegar al centro de la ciudad, los productos que compra son, vegetales, golosinas, cosas para la higiene personal, etc., los productos que le llegan a dejar son más que todo bebidas y productos como detergentes.
  
El préstamo que esta solicitando a Fundación Campo, es para comprar más productos para la tienda; ya que con el paso del tiempo la demanda que el mantiene es grande y los productos son insuficientes para poder satisfacer las necesidades de sus cliente, también comprara un estante para colocar los productos con los que  él quiere ampliar su tienda.

Pues con la adquisición del préstamo podrá satisfacer las necesidades de sus clientes además de tener una mayor clientela con la cual generara un mayor ingreso a su familia para pode satisfacer cómodamente las necesidades de su familia.
 
Su sueño es, construir un local mas grande para la tienda ya que él posee bastante espacio donde vive; ya que es uno de sus sueños como empresario emprendedor que demuestra ser, al igual poder brindar una mayor educación para sus nietos cuando estos ya sean mayores porque uno de sus sueños es el poder ver a sus nietos graduados como profesionales.
texts.en:
Pedro is 50 years old and has a partner and 2 children. He is very well known, being one of the most active people in his community, and makes a living running a small and very modest shop. He lives with his wife and 2 grandchildren, a girl aged 8 years and a boy of 3, and obviously adores them. He works hard for them every day and has been running the shop for 6 years, which gives them a small income. Before he had the shop he used to work on a farm but the farm closed because of poor management and so now he only has the income from the shop to live on.

He has to travel to the city to buy the majority of the products he sells in his shop. He has to travel 64 kilometres by collective transport to the city centre, which takes him an hour and a half. The products he buys are vegetables, sweets, personal hygiene items etc., and items which are delivered to him are mainly drinks and products such as detergents.

The loan he is asking for from Fundación Campo is to buy more products for the shop. Over time the demand for his products has become greater and he has insufficient products to be able to satisfy the needs of his customers. He will also buy a shelf to display the products with which he wants to expand the shop.
  
By obtaining the loan he will be able to satisfy the needs of his customers as well as having a larger clientele, which will give him a bigger income for his family and enable him to comfortably meet the family's needs.

His dream is to build bigger premises for the shop and he already has plenty of space where he lives. This is one of the dreams which he has, as the entrepreneurial businessman he has shown himself to be. He also wants to provide his grandchildren with further education when they are older because one of his dreams is to be able to see them qualify as professionals.

loans.use: to buy more products for the shop.

loans.name: Heak's Group

texts.en: Heak is a rice and corn farmer in the local area of Thmor Koul district of Battambang province. She is married and has eight children.  She has been a farmer for about 20 years. Now, her main challenge is the shortage of working capital to support her farmland. Therefore, she applied for a new loan with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner) by forming a group of three members. Heak is a fourth time-borrower who has repaid back her past three loans with success. The loans have helped her to provide decent food for her kids. Now, she is the leader of her group. She is seeking 1,000,000 KHR in order to buy insecticide for her corn field. She hopes to increase the yield and revenue so she can improve her living conditions.

loans.use: To buy insecticide for her corn field

loans.name: Maria Belen

texts.es:
Belén es una joven de 21 años, es soltera y trabaja duro para poder pagar los estudios en su universidad, pues su sueño es ser una profesional con excelencia para poder desarrollarse como empresaria. Belén residía en una ciudad que fue azotada por varias amenazas de erupción volcánica y por lo cual la actividad económica se redujo por la poca afluencia de turistas, es por esto que ella decidió migrar al Cantón de Salcedo en donde vive actualmente y está ubicado en la parte Oriente de Cotopaxi una de las provincias más importantes de la Sierra ecuatoriana. En Salcedo existen varios atractivos turísticos como lagunas y balnearios que ofrecen deportes extremos para sus turistas aventureros, sin embargo la principal actividad que desarrollan en este pueblo es la agricultura y en menor cuantía la ganadería. Los productos agrícolas más comercializados son granos como arveja, fréjol, lenteja, haba y también varias frutas y verduras. La producción de leche y sus derivados abastece la distribución interna y el excedente se envía a la Región Costa en productos ya procesados. La crianza de animales es también muy favorable por el  clima agradable del que se goza en el Cantón. A pesar de estas actividades productivas, hay índices muy preocupantes de analfabetismo y de pobreza por necesidades básicas insatisfechas como por ejemplo el servicio de alcantarillado que solo lo tienen el 25% de los hogares. 
Uno de los alimentos típicos de esta ciudad son los “helados de salcedo” productos que guardan una gran historia y tienen más de 60 años en el mercado, su receta fue descubierta en los interiores de un convento por una de las madres franciscanas  quienes anhelaban mejores días para la comunidad, es por esto que inicialmente este producto tenía el nombre inicial de “Helado de las Monjas” que era comercializado solamente en el interior del convento pero la demanda era tan alta que luego los vendían de forma ambulante generando así trabajo para varias personas del pueblo. Finalmente varias familias tuvieron acceso a la fórmula que ahora los hace famosos en todo el país e incluso internacionalmente, pues son exportados alrededor de 80.000 unidades cada año a varios países. 
Belén nos cuenta esta historia de memoria pues trabajó en un sitio de venta de helados de salcedo y hace un año emprendió con su propio local de helados en donde vende también víveres y golosinas, es de gran ayuda para ella que su local esté ubicado en un lugar estratégico en el centro de la ciudad en donde pasean varios turistas. Invierte 5 horas cada día a la atención de su local, pues varias horas también debe asistir a la universidad y cumplir tareas. Ahora está solicitando un préstamo que lo utilizará en varias mejoras y arreglos a su vivienda que está deteriorada y además con muchos trabajos pendientes que le causan molestias a diario. Aunque Belén no ha tenido la oportunidad de asistir a las capacitaciones que ofrece Fundación Alternativa, ella ha encontrado en esta IMF el apoyo y asesoría necesarios para dar paso firme a su crecimiento. Ella considera muy importante el apoyo que varios microempresarios y emprendedores reciben de todo el mundo a través de Kiva y se siente muy motivada para seguir y cumplir sus obligaciones pues así no solo ella sino también su país presentarán una excelente imagen ante el mundo.
texts.en:
Belén is a 21-year-old young woman. She is single and works very hard in order to pay for her university studies. Belén's dream is to become a professional businesswoman. She lived in a city that was devastated by volcanic eruptions. As a result, the local economy has suffered from a drop in tourism. That is why Belén decided to move to the canton of Salcedo, where she currently lives. Salcedo is located in the Oriente de Cotopaxi, one of the most important provinces in the mountain region of Ecuador. 

In Salcedo, there are many tourist attractions such as lakes, hot springs, and extreme sports for adventure tourists. However, the principal economic activity in this town is agriculture and (to a smaller extent) livestock. The most abundant crops include peas, beans, lentils, and other fruits and vegetables. Milk and dairy products are also produced for local markets and the excess processed items are sent to the coastal region. This is a good region for raising livestock due to the favorable climate the canton enjoys. Despite this productivity, there are some very concerning illiteracy and poverty rates. Many basic needs are not met. For example, the sewage system only reaches 25% of homes in the area. 

One of the typical foods of the city are the "Salcedo ice creams", products that have a great history and have been sold for over 60 years. The recipe was discovered in the convent of some Franciscan nuns who desired better days for the community. For this reason, the first name for the dessert was "the nuns' ice cream" and was sold only from the convent. However, demand grew so high that they began to sell the ice cream in the streets, which created jobs for the people of the town. Finally, various families learned the now famous recipe, which is recognized throughout the country and internationally. Each year, about 80,000 units are exported to various countries.

Belén knows the history by heart because she worked at a site that sells the Salcedo ice cream. A year ago, she opened her own ice cream shop from which she also sells groceries and sweets. This is a great help to her because her store is located in a strategic place in the center of the city where many tourists pass by. Belén works five hours each day at her store because she also attends classes and has homework from the university.

Belén is requesting a loan to do some repairs on her home, which is deteriorating and is a daily nuisance. Although Belén has not had the opportunity to attend the trainings that Fundación Alternativa offers, she enjoys the support and advice this institution provides to help her grow. She thinks the support Kiva offers to small businesses and business owners all over the world is very important. She is motivated to fulfill all of her obligations because, in this way, not only she but also her country will make a good impression on the world.

loans.use: to do some repairs on her home.

loans.name: San Pedro Group

texts.es:
El comité “San Pedro” es de la ciudad de Santani, específicamente de la comunidad de Guayaibi, una zona un poco alejada del centro de la ciudad y de muy difícil acceso, ya que cuando hay inclemencias del clima ya no tiene medio de ingresar.
La Sra. Juliana tiene una despensa donde vende los productos de su propio plantío, como mandioca, maíz, poroto, también huevo. Es una señora muy emprendedora que está luchando arduamente por crecer y por salir adelante y  ayudar a su familia.
Solicita de este crédito para la compra de otros insumos para su despensa, como ser leche, carne, frutas y demás y seguir trabajando de esa forma.
texts.en:
The communal bank "San Pedro" is from the city of Santani, specifically from the community of Guayaibi, which is an area quite far from the center of the city and with a very difficult access.  During bad weather there is no way to get there.

Juliana runs a store where she sells her own produce, such as yucca plant, corn, beans and also eggs.  She is a very enterprising woman who is working hard to grow and get ahead as well as help her family.

She is requesting a loan to buy other supplies for her store such as milk, meat, fruit and other items, so she can continue with her business.

loans.use: To buy milk, meat, fruit and other items.

loans.name: Las Mercedes Group

texts.es:
El comité “Las Mercedes” esta creciendo gracias a la ayuda de las capacitaciones que están recibiendo, ya que son de una comunidad alejada, y la fundación ha optado por ayudarlas y que de esa forma puedan ir creciendo.
La Sra. Mercedes, una de ellas, es vendedora ambulante y utilizara su crédito para traer productos para la vente, como ser gorras, bufandas y medias para generar más ingresos. Ella quiere seguir trabajando y ayudando a su familia.
Ella se define como una persona muy trabajadora que tiene como meta ir mejorando los ingresos de su familia.
texts.en:
The communal bank "Las Mercedes" is growing thanks to the training the group is receiving.  The members are from a distant community and the foundation has decided to help them so they can increase their business.

Mercedes is one of the members and she works as a street vendor.  She will use the loan to buy products such as hats, scarves and socks to sell and generate an income.  She wants to continue working and helping her family.

Mercedes defines herself as a very hard worker whose goal is to improve her family's income.

loans.use: To buy hats, scarves and socks.

loans.name: Soledad

texts.en:
This is Soledad. She previously accessed a 50,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan that she used to purchase merchandise items and products needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help for her children’s education and in her personal, household and business expenditures.

She would like to apply for another 50,000 PHP loan to buy additional supplies and merchandise products like clothing, footwear, undergarments and cosmetics needed in her business. The more items she has on display and available on hand, the better. More items to sell will result in better profit. Her profits from business will definitely help her to sustain her children’s education and daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 

Soledad’s dream is to expand her business and have more clients. She hopes that her children will finish their studies. She meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week, and this is where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community clients, of which Soledad is one, are organized into fellowship groups of 15 to 30 members who meet on a weekly basis. There they share stories of their work, repay microfinance loans and draw strength and inspiration from their study of the Word of God.

loans.use: to pay for additional supplies and merchandise products like clothing, footwear, undergarments and cosmetics needed in her business.

loans.name: Cresencia

texts.en:
Cresencia is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a food vending business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing 16,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food vending business.

Cresencia has been in this business for four years. Cresencia earns more income from buying and reselling ready-to-wear clothing.

She successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her food vending and ready-to-wear business.

Cresencia has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save enough money for business expansion in the future.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food production business.

loans.name: Sreymom's Group

texts.en: A young mother of one little kid, Sreymom is a citizen from the Kror Kor district of Pursat. For the sake of her family, she manages one and half hectares of rice farming as the main income source. To supplement the family’s income, her husband also works for others for a wage. Sreymom is a second-time borrower with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner). She has used her past loan wisely to support her living especially in providing good food for her child. For this cycle, she will spend her loan portion on buying potash for her crops. She hopes that she can gain a yield better than before.

loans.use: To buy potash for her crops

loans.name: Sovin's Group

texts.en: A villager from Bakan district of Pursat Province, Sovin is married and has three kids who are still in school.  She struggles in making a living via one hectare of rice farming. Besides helping her on the farmland, her husband uses his spare time to earn extra income through his fishing business and working for others for a wage.  She has been involved in her current business for 15 years, earning about 12,000 KHR per day. Sovin is a second-cycle client with VisionFund (Kiva’s partner) and is now leading a group of four to apply for a new loan. After the past loan which she has repaid with success, she feels confident that she can improve her family's living conditions even more. For this cycle, she and two fellow group members are seeking 1,000,000 KHR each while the remaining member is applying for 1,200,000 KHR. As the leader, Sovin will spend her loan portion to buy fertilizer for her farmland and to buy a pig for raising for extra income. She hopes that she can increase her income to improve her lifestyle.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for her farmland

loans.name: Kuljamila

texts.ru: Кулжамиле 53 года, она вдова, мать -героиня, имеет 7 детей (3 сына и 4 дочери). 5 старших детей женаты и проживают отдельно. После смерти мужа в поисках дополнительного дохода для своей семьи Кулжамила решила заняться полеводством и животноводством. На сегодняшний день она имеет небольшое хозяйство, а в хозяйстве у нее имеется: 2 дойные коровы, 2 теленка, и 15 голов мелкого рогатого скота. Также у нее в наличии имеется 0,90 ГА земельного надела, где она ежегодно сажает картофель и фасоль. В целях дальнейшего развития своего хозяйства, Кулжамила обратилась в Микрофинансовый Банк «Бай-Тушум и Партнеры» за кредитом в сумме 40 000 сом(KGS) на покупку телят. На доходы от кредита Кулжамила планирует увеличить поголовье скота, а в будущем хочет сделать ремонт дома.
texts.en: Kuljamila is a 53-year-old widow and "Hero Mother" who has seven children (three sons and four daughters).  Her five eldest children are married and live on their own.  In search of supplemental income for her family after the death of her husband, Kuljamila decided to start raising crops and animals.  Today she has a small farm with two dairy cows, two calves and 15 head of sheep and goats.  She also has .90 hectares of land, where she plants potatoes and beans.  With the goal of increasing her business, Kuljamila has turned to the Bai-Tushum Microfinance Bank for a loan of 40,000 som (KGS) to buy calves.  Her children help her run her farm and her family is well-respected among the villagers.  She plans on using the money from the loan to increase her head of livestock and she wants to make repairs to her home in the future.  Kuljamila is one of three people in the "Kelechek-N" group.

loans.use: to buy calves

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To convert his conventional coffee crop to organic and buy organic fertilizers.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to re-sow his farm and buy fertiliser.

loans.name: Misbha

texts.en:
Misbha is a 37-year-old married woman and mother of five children. She is one of the good clients of Kashf Foundation and has been happily running her own beauty parlor for many years. She offers many services to her customers such as makeup, hair styling and facials. She makes enough money to provide the basic necessities of life to her family through her business. 

Previously, she took a loan to purchase some furniture and tools. Currently, she seeks a loan of 45,000 PKR (Pakistani rupees) to buy hair-care products, skin products and creams of bleaching and whitening in large quantities. She is in her fifth loan cycle with a good repayment history. She wishes to utilize part of the revenues to provide a good and quality education to her children through all her hard work. She is thankful to Kiva and Kashf Foundation for their support.

loans.use: to buy hair-care products, skin products and creams of bleaching and whitening.

loans.name: Kotognotala Ii Group

texts.fr:
Les neuf  membres du KOTOGNOTALA II sont  des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 35 ans et ont en moyenne 6 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à Fofanabougou un des villages de la commune de Guégnaka,  préfecture de Dioîla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de micro finance Soro yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités en début d’hivernage. Les spéculations cultivées sont  l’arachide, du mil et du sésame. Elles sont à leur quatrième  collaboration avec l’institution.
Avec ce prêt,  Awa la deuxième de la gauche vers la droite  dans le rang des assises, compte acheter les intrants, les petits équipements et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir environs 1 ha de mil et d’arachide 
Les productions sont vendues au niveau de la ville de Fana, après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. Elle espère  réaliser un bénéfice  de 85 000F CFA environs par campagne.
texts.en:
The nine members of the group "KOTOGNOTALA II" are married women, who average 35 years of age and six children each. The women live for the most part in polygamous families in Fofanabougou, a village in Commune de Guégnaka, Préfecture de Dioïla, in Région de Koulikoro (2nd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The women are collaborating with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso with the goal of better organizing their work at the start of the rainy season. And they are on their fourth collaboration with the institution. The crops grown are peanuts, millet, and sesame.

With this loan, Awa, who is sitting second from the left in the photo, intends to purchase farm inputs and sundry equipment and to cover the cost of plowing to maintain 1 hectare of millet and peanuts. 

After the harvest, the produce is sold in Fana City to men and women customers. She hopes to make a profit of about 85,000 francs CFA per planting.

loans.use: to pay for plowing, weeding, seeds, fertilizer, herbicide, and sundry equipment.

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en:
Mohamad is a 43-year-old married father of three children, who are enrolled in a public school because of his low income business. His wife doesn't work, her main responsibility is taking care of her beloved family members. 
Mohamad works hard to develop his business and improve his family's standard of living, that's why he is applying for a loan from Kiva's partner Al Majmoua, to undertake the necessary maintenance and register his car which is essential for his business facilitation.
He works in the construction domain, specialising in painting houses and shops for the past thirty years.
This long experience has provided him with customers' trust and support. This car will help him expand his working region, and transport his tools and requested items easily.
He is working hard to open a shop for selling paints and painting tools.

loans.use: to undertake necessary maintenance and register his car

loans.name: Sabougnouma  I Group

texts.fr:
Les dix membres du  SABOUGNOUMA  I sont des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 37 ans et ont en moyenne 3 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à Barakolobougou un des villages de la commune de Guégnaka,  préfecture de Dioîla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de micro finance Soro yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités en début d’hivernage. Les spéculations cultivées sont l’arachide, du mil et du haricot. Elles sont à leur sixième  collaboration avec l’institution.
Avec ce prêt,  Djeneba la deuxième personne à gauche dans le rang des assises, compte acheter les intrants, les petits équipements et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir environs 1 ha de mil et d’arachide 
Les productions sont vendues au niveau de la ville de Fana, après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. Elle espère réaliser un bénéfice  de 90.000F CFA environs par campagne.
texts.en:
The ten members of the group "SABOUGNOUMA I" are married women, who average 37 years of age and three children each. The women live for the most part in polygamous families in Barakolobougou, a village in Commune de Guégnaka, Préfecture de Dioïla, in Région de Koulikoro (2nd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The women are collaborating with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso with the goal of better organizing their work at the start of the rainy season. And they are on their sixth collaboration with the institution. The crops grown are peanuts, millet, and beans.

With this loan, Djeneba, who is the second person sitting from the left, intends to purchase farm inputs and sundry equipment and to cover the cost of plowing to maintain 1 hectare of millet and peanuts. 

After the harvest, the produce is sold in Fana City to men and women customers. She hopes to make a profit of about 90,000 francs CFA per planting.

loans.use: to pay for plowing, weeding, seeds, fertilizer, herbicide and sundry equipment.

loans.name: Hanadi

texts.en:
Hanadi is a 45-year-old widowed mother of four children; she has sacrificed her whole life to provide them with the necessary standards of living since her husband passed away.

Hanadi has been working in selling lingerie and sleeping suits since 14 years ago. In March 2013, she opened her own shop to increase her income in order to stay capable of replying to her increasing family needs.

She is applying for a loan from Kiva's partner Al Majmoua to increase her business merchandise with a special summer collection. She is very anxious about this loan, and is willing to invest it in a well-managed way to make sure that one day, she will open additional branches and expand her working zone in addition to diversifying her products to attract customers' attention.

loans.use: To increase her business merchandise with a special summer collection.

loans.name: Sabougnouma Ii Group

texts.fr:
Les  membres de  SABOUGNOUMA II sont  des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 36 ans et ont en moyenne 4 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à Barakolobougou un des villages de la commune de Guégnaka,  préfecture de Dioîla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de micro finance Soro yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités en début d’hivernage. Les spéculations cultivées sont l’arachide, du mil et du haricot. Elles sont à leur sixième  collaboration avec l’institution.
Avec ce prêt,  Foune  la personne au milieu dans le rang des debout, compte acheter les intrants, les petits équipements et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir environs 1 ha de mil et d’arachide 
Les productions sont vendues au niveau de la ville de Fana, après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. Elle espère  réaliser  un bénéfice  de 95 000F CFA environs par campagne.
texts.en:
The members of the group "SABOUGNOUMA II" are married women, who average 36 years of age and four children each. The women live for the most part in polygamous families in Barakolobougou, a village in Commune de Guégnaka, Préfecture de Dioïla, in Région de Koulikoro (2nd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The women are collaborating with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso with the goal of better organizing their work at the start of the rainy season. And they are on their sixth collaboration with the institution. The crops grown are peanuts, millet, and beans.

With this loan, Foune, who is standing in the middle of her row, intends to purchase farm inputs and sundry equipment and to cover the cost of plowing to maintain 1 hectare of millet and peanuts. 

After the harvest, the produce is sold in Fana City to men and women customers. She hopes to make a profit of about 95,000 francs CFA per planting.

loans.use: to pay for plowing, weeding, seeds, fertilizer, herbicide and sundry equipment.

loans.name: Daniel

texts.es: El Sr. Daniel  se dedica  a la confección de prendas de vestir desde hace ya varios años aprendió el oficio de confección cuando salió del país a trabajar buscando un futuro mejor para el,  ya que el confecciona chamarras y ropa  deportiva, tiene su taller se encuentra en su mismo domicilio que es en la en la localidad de El Torno,  Este préstamo es su  Primera secuencia dentro de la institución, el Sr. Daniel  va a utilizar este préstamo para la  compra de telas por rollo para la confección de prendas de vestir por mayor, Su razón para solicitar este préstamo es para incremento de capital de inversión,  El Sr. Daniel  enfrenta retos en su negocio que son aumentar sus ingresos y va a utilizar los beneficios invirtiendo en la compra de materiales para la confección de prendas de buena calidad y así tener más pedidos de clientes. Ya que esta época tiene mucha demanda, el  Sr. Daniel  es una persona muy trabajadora se siente feliz y agradecido con la institución por el apoyo brindado ya que esta es su única fuente de ingresos.
texts.en:
Daniel has been in the sewing business for several years and learned the trade when he left his country in search of a better future for himself.  He makes jackets and sport clothes in the workshop he has in his home in the town of El Torno.  This is his first loan through the institution and he will use it to buy rolls of fabric to make clothing to sell wholesale.  The reason he needs the loan is to increase his working capital.

Daniel has challenges such as increasing his income and he plans to use his profits to buy materials to make quality apparel in an effort to increase orders.  This is the season when there is a lot of demand.  Daniel is a very hard working person and he is happy and grateful to the institution for the support he is receiving since this is his only source of income.

loans.use: To buy rolls of fabric.

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en:
Hellen is a Kiva borrower who describes herself as ambitious. She has taken a loan of 55,500 KES (Kenyan shillings) to buy a water dispenser and a fridge that will benefit four members of her family. She sells clothes to earn an income and she faces a challenge of competition from other sellers.

The dispenser will enable the family to store clean drinking water and also be able to access warm water without necessarily having to boil it. This is her second loan with SMEP DTM. Her previous loan of 20,000 KES was repaid successfully. She hopes that in the future, she will meet her family's needs.

loans.use: buy a water dispenser and a fridge.

loans.name: Eugenia

texts.en:
This is Eugenia. She previously accessed a loan of 10,000 PHP that she used to buy more quantities of biscuits for repackaging. Her earnings were a big help for the education of her children and in their personal, household and business expenditures.

She would like to apply for another loan of 15,000 PHP to buy more quantities of biscuits for repackaging. The more items displayed at the store the better. More items to sell will result in better profit. Her profits from business will definitely help sustain her daily needs and educational expenses of her children. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Eugenia hopes that her business stays longer and dreams of giving her family a good future. She meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week, where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy more quantities of biscuits for repackaging.

loans.name: Aggrey

texts.en:
Aggrey has five children between ages one and five. He operates a retail shop in a market area where he sells sugar, salt, cooking oil, and other items to earn a living. Aggrey describes himself as God-fearing. His major business challenge is poor infrastructure.

Aggrey is requesting a 12,900 KES loan to buy a gas cooker. He hopes that in the future he will expand his business to the wholesale level.

loans.use: to buy a gas cooker

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy fertilizer, herbicides, pesticides, insecticides, and other supplies.

loans.name: Yoer

texts.en:
Yoer, 53, is widowed and lives in a village of the Moung Russey district of Battambang province. She has five children. She is a rice farmer who grows rice on five hectares of farmland. She has been in the rice farming business for 25 years, earning about 23,000 KHR per day to feed her family. 
Yoer has been with VisionFund for four cycles and she completely repaid the past loans which have helped her family relieve their financial burden and improve their livelihood. Now requesting another loan with VisionFund, Yoer will buy rice seeds, pesticides and fertilizers for her farmland. With this loan, she hopes to increase her crop yields and earn more income to improve her family’s living conditions.

loans.use: To buy rice seeds, pesticides and fertilizers for her farmland

loans.name: Ty's Group

texts.en: Ty is 34 years old and married. She has four dependent children to care for, as they are still in school. Her one hectare of rice farming land and her half-hectare of cassava growing land, which she has occupied for several years, are the main sources of her family’s income and produce about 20,000 KHR per day. This is the first microloan for Ty’s Group from VisionFund (Kiva’s partner). There are three members in the group, including Ty as the leader. Ty is applying for 500,000 KHR, while her co-members are is applying for 300,000 KHR each. As the leader, she will spend her loan portion to buy good cassava seedlings, potash, and insecticide for her farmland. She hopes that she will grow her crops in a healthy way and make a good profit for her family.

loans.use: to buy good cassava seedlings, potash, and insecticide for her farm.

location.town: Siem Reap Province, Srey Snom district

loans.name: Humberto

texts.es: Don Humberto es originario de Estelí, vive con su esposa y una  hija quien tiene a cargo. El comenzó  su negocio hace mucho tiempo, con su trabajo logro brindar estudio a sus hijos quienes hoy en día son profesionales  y fuente de ingreso para  él, también logro comprar su casa donde es buen punto de venta. Solicita este préstamo para comprar productos al por mayor  tales como: granos básicos, arroz, azúcar, aceite, maíz etc. y lograr satisfacer las necesidades de sus clientes.  Su meta futura es construir su casa y mantener un mejor nivel de vida, su meta próxima es aumentar sus ingresos atravez de su negocio, él se siente muy agradecido ya que a través de kiva  puede solicitar este préstamo que será de mucha ayuda para él.  Sus expectativas en su negocio es, ser líder en el mercado.
texts.en:
Humberto is a native of Esteli who lives with his wife and a dependant daughter. 

He started his business a long time ago. Through his work he has managed to give his children an education. Today, they are professionals and provide him with a source of income. He also managed to buy his home where he has a good sales location. 

He is requesting this loan to buy wholesale goods such as basic grains, rice, sugar, oil, corn etc., to meet his customers' needs. 

His dream for the future is to construct a house and to maintain a better quality of life. His short-term goal is to increase his income through his business.

He is very grateful that he can apply for this loan through Kiva. It will be a great help to him. His business aspiration is to become a market leader.

loans.use: to buy wholesale goods such as basic grains, rice, sugar, oil, corn etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To renovate his coffee plantation.

loans.name: Koussar

texts.en: Koussar is a 39-year-old married woman. She has been actively running a ‘Tandoor’ in her locality for many years. A tandoor (clay oven) is used for cooking chapattis and naan especially in Pakistan. She cooks chapattis and naan with flour, salt and oil then sells them to the people of her community. She also takes orders from nearby hotels and makes enough money to have a decent life.  She is a loving mother of five children and is responsible for their food, health and education. She is trying hard to fulfill their basic necessities through her business. For the improvement of her business she applied for a loan of 50,000 PKR to purchase more sacks of flour and packs of salt and oil. She is in her 7th loan cycle with a good loan history. She hopes to increase her net income and wishes to provide good and quality education to her children.

loans.use: to purchase more sacks of flour and packs of salt and oil.

loans.name: Shehnaz

texts.en:
Shehnaz is a 51-year-old married woman. She has been successfully running a general store with her husband at the corner of her house. The man shown in the photo is her husband, who purchases stock of goods from a wholesale market, then they sell to their customers at reasonable prices. They have maintained many contacts over the years and make enough amount of income to support their family. 

She is in her fifth loan cycle and has shown good repayment behavior. To make her store fully stocked, Shehnaz requested a loan for 40,000 PKR (Pakistani rupees), which she will use to buy stock of rice, oil, sugar and flour from the market at lower rates. In this way, she would be able to meet the increasing demand consistently. She wishes to utilize part of her revenues to increase her business capital.

loans.use: to buy stock of rice, oil, sugar and flour.

loans.name: Sabougnouma Iii Group

texts.fr:
Les  membres de SABOUGNOUMA III sont  des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 43 ans et ont en moyenne 3 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à Barakolobougou un des villages de la commune de Guégnaka,  préfecture de Dioîla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de micro finance Soro yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités en début d’hivernage. Les spéculations cultivées sont  l’arachide, du mil et du haricot. Elles sont à leur sixième  collaboration avec l’institution.
